content: What can I say. Simply amazing!

I am an intermediate player about to break 1100, so I got the Chessbase Online app to better prepare my openings. I have trouble against strong players who are 1300 or above, so I decided to solidify my knowledge of the lines I play - the Yugoslav Attack, Albin Counter-gambit, Caro Cann, etc.  My chess coach has been making me go to lectures on the middlegame and tactics, but they are incredibly boring and mostly consist of some grandmaster reviewing a game for an hour and talking about things like â€œweak squaresâ€ and â€œcounter playâ€. I figured that while in the lectures, I could continue my study of openings surreptitiously on my phone, thereby continuing my chess progress while also keeping my coach happy.  I quickly found out that the app is not letting me do this. I have been trying to use the app for over a week, but it just gives me a â€œconnectingâ€ message â€“ for hour after hour, without ever connecting. Very suspicious.  I don't think it's right that Chessbase sold me the app for $9.13 when it's completely useless to me. It's obvious that they're blocking me somehow... the only alternative I can think of, is that they are largely incompetent at providing cloud services...
replyContent: Could you please describe the problem to tsukrov@chessbase.com?

The other thing is that the games are not annotated, therefore they should be players property. For these two reasons I believe that the app is overpriced.

This app gives you access to a big online database of games. It lets you search through that database for players and/or positions. If you want to discover the opening repertoire of a particular player, this app will do all the work for you. Equally, if you just want to access a particular game and play through it, it's fairly easy using this app. The options are not as intuitive as they could be, but once you become familiar with them it is a fairly easy program to use. It does crash/hang occasionally, which isn't ideal, and there's no built in analysis engine, which is a shame. Despite these shortcomings, it's quite good. If you want to study the games of other players, using an Android device, then this is the app for you. If you want to play chess against your Android device, get 'Chess Genius' or 'Shredder'.

content: Problem:  not connecting to online base and book on samsung s3. Attempts: (1) Deleted Great Games pgn as instructed.  (2) Checked to see if I have latest OS, which I do, 4.3 . (3) Checked memory for RAM and storage.  I have more than a one gig for RAM to spare and 16 gigs for storage.  (4) rebooted phone several times.  What a waste of money this once great app turned out to be.

OK, let's start with the fact that the chessbase app can't open proprietary chessbase files. That's right, it can't open its own files, only pgn.  Want to read some books in chessbase format? Can't do it with chessbase online.  The search function is very poor, you can't get back more than 1000 results and the only way to save them to a personal database is one at a time. Good luck creating databases on your opening lines one game at a time. Oh, and store them as pgn, that's all chessbase online reads.  Finally, the app crashes a lot! Every time it does, you lose whatever analysis you've created, unless you save the file after every few moves entered.  I'm left wondering what features this expensive app has that Scid vs. PC for free doesn't have.

I love the combination of opening with chess engine, but there are some missing features that would really seal the deal and make this the only engine I turn to: 1. Saving your last position. The app crashes a lot, and it would be great if it remembered the last position. 2. Pasting pngs. 3. Offline database.

Stunning in what it can deliver even to a very ordinary chess player like myself.   All those books with lengthy variations and analyses suddenly make sense - because the vast ChessBase database finds almost all games (quickly and easily) and you can play through including adding multi-branching variations and comments if you like.   As a bonus the app includes "Great Games" data file 500 commented games covering master level chess from the 1850s to 2000s. These games can be accessed even offline ! Awesome support from dev to iron out  hiccups on N7.  Bear in mind as other reviewers point out this app does not play chess against you. It is designed to allow you to access and play through games stored either locally on the device or from the enormous (and constantly updating) ChessBase archive. If you want to play through all of Fischer - Spassky or explore the delights of the classical or hypermodern eras or keep up to date with latest super-GM tournaments this app is simply brilliant.
Wonderful... Good support service.
Absolutely love it..! Very practical and easy to use. Best app for android ever.

I have CB9 on my PC so was expecting good things from this app but as has been said elsewhere it is very limited for a paid for app.  Its inability to read CB's native standard file .cbh is inexcusable.  This means you have to duplicate your databases into .pgn and subsequently keep both up to date.  I cannot find how to search by position on my saved databases therefore I assume its not available either.  The playback board is clumsily designed making playing through games awkward as the buttons are often mis-hit.  I will persevere in the hope that these niggles are ironed out but if I was wiser I would have spent my Â£3.49 on a pint of Guinness & experimented with the free apps available.  Edit - Wow!!  The March update is a game changer.  I'm increasing my rating to 4 stars due to the increased ease of using it as a database.  Saving games & positions has improved drastically.  Now worth the money.  Some quibbles remain eg not .cbh compatible & some other improvements can be made but am now confident Chessbase will get to these.  Well done!!

To be fixed Missing features Please add: some engine to analyze the position, some way to get the moves Player X played in all his games in that position(like as black he played against 1e4 32times 1...c5 12 times 1...e6, etc),statistics for his results-to find out that he scores only 25% against 1c4. The issue with exiting is fixed.
Rating went from 3 to 5 stars with 2.0 update, and keeps getting better - they just added null moves! Would still like to see support for chessbase files, like cbv.

This application has still a long, long way to go. I will make it simple for you. Purchase it only if you think that access to the ChessBase game database is worth that money (I do), because that is what it is.  I rated this 2 stars, not because it has no AI to play against or engine to analyse but because of the poor user experience for my mobile phone. First, the board is too small and it is hard to move the pieces and second the buttons to advance to the next move are also too small so you end up clicking the button close, which turns the board the other way around. Quite annoying sometimes as you can understand.  If you want to play against AI or analyse position, simply go for free options like "Droidfish" or "Mobialia Chess (Ads)".

This app is particularly useful to,check opening lines. Errr... That's about it! Move input is very annoying, you can't use tap & tap, you have to drag around all the pieces. Can't create .pgn files with different variations (or it's too difficult), can't work with other pgn files properly. No analysis engine. No .cbh compatibility, no Fen code twitter export, can't save your work... If you still have a pocket PC, pocket Fritz is like... 5 times better. Enough said!
Managed to get it run by a simple firmware upgrade. Seems like a useful app.

I've had Chessbase for several days now, and it is exactly what I was looking for.  In addition to coming with a set of games in a pgn file, it offers access to online games on their web site as well.  This morning as I started on the chess puzzle in the paper, I noticed the puzzle came from a game played last year. When I searched for it, I found the full game available on the chessbase site.  Replaying 1000's of games with full annotation is a great way to learn chess.  Chessbase was able to access another set of annotated games I'd independently downloaded.  They also offer an "opening search" which I puzzled over for a bit.  I finally realized that by selecting a series of moves, Chessbase looks for games that start with these moves, and you can select one from the corresponding list of games.  This was one case where a little "help" might have been in order - there is none - and that would be the only criticism I have.  However, the interface works well enough to have allowed me to figure that out on my own.  A little help on how to save a game would be good too.  Nevertheless, a good tool.
Does what it advertises and does it good. This is a database not an engine. Nice work

It's NOT easy to prepare for opponent. Bought this app only for that feature. One should be able to see a statistic tree for a single player (one tree for white ofc and one for black) just as one would do in the PC program. Even when I search my opponent's games they don't show up in time order, making it ever harder to see what he plays in his most recent games.
